content.description: Start almost laying down matched on the lowest jug. Get up to that good second jug. Find your feet, and dyno to the lip. Some crimps in the roof probably allow for static beta. Mantel.
content.location: If youâ€™ve found Giants Palm, keep walking. Actually it is better if you get above Giant's Palm and follow the trail keeping the hill down to your right. Soon this problem comes up on the right just around a corner.

content.description: In the summer days, this is a very buggy spot due to the nature of the location (practically 1/4 of the boulder is in the water), but I can promise it's a fun little problem. The start hold is a big jug located on the lower left corner with a sapling growing behind it. Make sure not to dip your toes in as you get good positioning above the water. Follow the crimps and slopers up the right side of the boulder, and make sure to get good use out of your heel! **hint!
content.location: It is 30 feet South of the Foley Caves - this is one of the final "big" rock formations alongside the water. The hill that has to be walked down to reach the boulder is very steep, so watch your feet-- you wouldn't want to slip here.

content.description: This is on a sharp, crimpy boulder. Make use of the sharp arete for your left hand, and get your right hand on a big, quartz undercling to start.
content.location: It is off to the right of Rapa Nui Rundown, about 10 feet to the right.

content.description: Follow the broken crack system up the center of the tall, narrow block. Despite an extensive cleaning, there is still enough dirt and green moss to make soloing this thing dangerous (bad landing). Climbing is good with the crux coming as you gain the groove below the hand crack.
content.protection: This takes a host of nuts, small cams, and a hand-sized piece for the upper crack. Also, it sets up easily for a solo TR.
content.location: It is on the obvious, tall and narrow block by the swampy caves area.

content.description: Petrified Wood Traverse is a fun traverse on a short boulder. It is a little covered in lichen. The footwork is the only tricky part. The rock may not actually be petrified wood, but it sure bears a resemblance!Avoid the possibly detached feet near the bottom which are obvious cheating.
content.protection: Pads will not be much help because of the slope. Make sure you have a spotter.
content.location: Follow the Forty Caves trailhead. At the first fork, turn right. When you see a boulder with a hollow the shape of a hand (Giant's Palm), turn left. Follow the trail and take the first left, then take the first right you see, which should be past a couple of uninteresting boulders. By this point, you should be on the blue trail. Follow the trail to the top of the hill, then turn left onto the yellow trail. When you get to the bottom of the hill, the route will be immediately to your left.The GPS coordinates are: 42.3460864, -71.5063296.

content.description: Making use of the Rapa Nui Rundown Boulder, this problem begins with a very obvious jug ledge. Work your way up the face with use of crimps, sidepulls, and of course, the small crack. The crux is obtaining the jug two feet about the crack. Be careful with some of the features, as the right side of the "crack" sounds slightly hollow. Better pics will be posted next time I head out to the caves.
content.location: It is directly on the left side around the corner from Rapa Nui Rundown.

content.description: Sit start on the big jugs/holes all the way low and right. Go more or less straight up from there. This has cool moves.
content.location: This boulder is just south of Wavy facing the stream. This is the right-most problem.

content.description: Giant's Palm is not the most interesting route, but it is a fun warm-up climb of just a few moves. When I saw the feature which looks like a hand, I just had to climb it. Start with all four limbs inside the hand, and climb straight upwards from there.
content.protection: A pad, if that.... The ground is soft.
content.location: Take the Forty Caves trailhead, then take a right at the first fork. The route is right across the stream.The GPS coordinates are: 42.3460864, -71.5063296.

content.description: Start low and left same as Fire in the Hole. Go right then up to the cool, curvy, undercling feature, then grab the lip, and mantel.
content.location: This boulder is just south of Wavy facing the stream. This is the middle problem.

content.description: Start on the low hold on the left end of the boulder. Work up and left to ultimately top out with your left hand slapping the slopey arete.
content.location: This boulder is just south of Wavy facing the stream. This is the leftmost problem on the boulder.

content.description: This is the area closest to the swamp on the opposite side of the property from the parking area. Some large erratics and shorter walls have potential for a handful of problems and shorter routes. These are better known for an abundance of small squeeze caves. It is an interesting area to explore, but bugs can be a major issue in the spring and summer months.
